guide.introduction:
Safely and effectively charge your USB-powered devices when you are away from your computer with this handy charger!

Please note: There have been reports that the Minty Boost has issues charging the iPhone 3GS.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Safely and effectively charge your USB-powered devices when you are away from your computer with this handy charger!

Please note: There have been reports that the Minty Boost has issues charging the iPhone 3GS.

Relevant parts
  • MintyBoost USB Charger Kit v3.0
  • 5V boost converter
  • 8-Pin IC Socket
  • Power supply capacitor 220uF/6.3V+
  • Bypass capacitor (0.1uF)
  • 1/8W 5% 3.3K resistor Orange Orange Red Gold
  • 1/8W 1% 75K resistor Violet Green Black Red Brown
  • 1/8W 1% 49.9K resistor Yellow White White Red Brown
  • 1N5818 (or 1N5817, etc) Schottky Diode
  • 10uH power inductor, at least 1A current capability
  • USB type A female jack
  • 2 x AA battery holder
  • Circuit board

lines.text: Check to make sure you have all of the necessary components to build version 3.0 of the Minty Boost.
lines.text_raw: Check to make sure you have all of the necessary components to build version 3.0 of the Minty Boost.

lines.text: Heat up your soldering iron and wet your sponge, and get ready to start!
lines.text_raw: Heat up your soldering iron and wet your sponge, and get ready to start!

lines.text: In location R5, insert the resistor with color code Orange-Orange-Red.
lines.text_raw: In location '''R5''', insert the resistor with color code Orange-Orange-Red.

lines.text: Resistors are not polarized, so it does not matter which direction you insert it.
lines.text_raw: Resistors are not polarized, so it does not matter which direction you insert it.

lines.text: Solder it in, and then clip the leads.
lines.text_raw: Solder it in, and then clip the leads.

lines.text: In locations R2 and R4, insert the blue resistors with color stripes of Violet-Green-Black-Red-Brown. Be sure to double-check the color code!
lines.text_raw: In locations '''R2''' and '''R4''', insert the blue resistors with color stripes of Violet-Green-Black-Red-Brown.  Be sure to double-check the color code!

lines.text: These are not polarized so it does not matter which direction you solder them in.
lines.text_raw: These are not polarized so it does not matter which direction you solder them in.

lines.text: Solder the leads and then clip the leads.
lines.text_raw: Solder the leads and then clip the leads.

lines.text: In locations R1 and R3, insert the resistors with color code Yellow-White-White-Red-Brown.
lines.text_raw: In locations '''R1''' and '''R3''', insert the resistors with color code Yellow-White-White-Red-Brown.

lines.text: Solder them in and then clip the leads.
lines.text_raw: Solder them in and then clip the leads.

lines.text: In locations C1 and C2, insert the two yellow ceramic capacitors.
lines.text_raw: In locations '''C1''' and '''C2''', insert the two yellow ceramic capacitors.

lines.text: The direction of these components does not matter.
lines.text_raw: The direction of these components does not matter.

lines.text: Solder them in and then clip the leads.
lines.text_raw: Solder them in and then clip the leads.

lines.text: In location D1, insert the black component with the silver stripe.
lines.text_raw: In location '''D1''', insert the black component with the silver stripe.

lines.text: Be sure to match up the silver stripe with the white stripe on the silk-screened image.
lines.text_raw: Be sure to match up the silver stripe with the white stripe on the silk-screened image.

lines.text: Solder it in and then clip the leads.
lines.text_raw: Solder it in and then clip the leads.

lines.text: The IC socket goes over the 3.3K Resistor, but make sure that you match up the notch on the socket with the notch on the silk-screened image.
lines.text_raw: The IC socket goes over the 3.3K Resistor, but make sure that you match up the notch on the socket with the notch on the silk-screened image.

lines.text: Be sure that the socket is flat on the PCB, and carefully solder the socket in.
lines.text_raw: Be sure that the socket is flat on the PCB, and carefully solder the socket in.

lines.text: In location L1 insert the inductor. It does not matter in which direction you insert the component.
lines.text_raw: In location '''L1''' insert the inductor.  It does not matter in which direction you insert the component.

lines.text: Solder it in and clip the leads.
lines.text_raw: Solder it in and clip the leads.

lines.text: In locations C3 and C4, insert the blue electrolytic capacitors.
lines.text_raw: In locations '''C3''' and '''C4''', insert the blue electrolytic capacitors.

lines.text: These capacitors are polarized, so make sure that the longer lead of the capacitor is inserted into the hole marked with a "+" on the silk-screened image.
lines.text_raw: These capacitors are polarized, so make sure that the longer lead of the capacitor is inserted into the hole marked with a "+" on the silk-screened image.

lines.text: Solder them in and then clip the wires.
lines.text_raw: Solder them in and then clip the wires.

lines.text: The red wire of the battery holder should be inserted into the hole marked with the "+".  The black wire should be inserted into the hole marked with the "-".
lines.text_raw: The red wire of the battery holder should be inserted into the hole marked with the "+".  The black wire should be inserted into the hole marked with the "-".

lines.text: Solder these wires in, and if necessary clip the leads.
lines.text_raw: Solder these wires in, and if necessary clip the leads.

lines.text: With the notch on the chip matched up with the notch on the socket, press the chip into the socket.
lines.text_raw: With the notch on the chip matched up with the notch on the socket, press the chip into the socket.

lines.text: Press it all the way into the socket to make sure it is secure.
lines.text_raw: Press it all the way into the socket to make sure it is secure.

lines.text: Begin by inserting two AA batteries into the battery holder.  Either rechargeable or alkaline batteries will work.
lines.text_raw: Begin by inserting two AA batteries into the battery holder.  Either rechargeable or alkaline batteries will work.

lines.text: Set your multimeter to read voltage, and place the red test lead on the leftmost pin and the black test lead on the rightmost pin.
lines.text_raw: Set your multimeter to read voltage, and place the red test lead on the leftmost pin and the black test lead on the rightmost pin.

lines.text: The voltage reading should be between 5V and 5.2V.  If not, then check to make sure your batteries are healthy (as well as the batteries in your multimeter).
lines.text_raw: The voltage reading should be between 5V and 5.2V.  If not, then check to make sure your batteries are healthy (as well as the batteries in your multimeter).

lines.text: Now check between the rightmost pin and the second and third pin.
lines.text_raw: Now check between the rightmost pin and the second and third pin.

lines.text: Your multimeter should measure around 2V.
lines.text_raw: Your multimeter should measure around 2V.

lines.text: Once everything checks out OK, remove the batteries and continue finishing the kit.
lines.text_raw: Once everything checks out OK, remove the batteries and continue finishing the kit.

lines.text: It should snap easily into place.
lines.text_raw: It should snap easily into place.

lines.text: Solder the four middle pins first and then the two outside mechanical pins.
lines.text_raw: Solder the four middle pins first and then the two outside mechanical pins.

lines.text: Before you start assembling the enclosure, connect the charger to an iPod or other USB-powered device.
lines.text_raw: Before you start assembling the enclosure, connect the charger to an iPod or other USB-powered device.

lines.text: Make sure that your device begins to charge.  Once you know that it is charging, you can build the enclosure.
lines.text_raw: Make sure that your device begins to charge.  Once you know that it is charging, you can build the enclosure.

lines.text: NOTE: The chip will get very hot while charging. This is normal so don't worry about it!
lines.text_raw: NOTE: The chip will get very hot while charging. This is normal so don't worry about it!

lines.text: Gather your empty Altoids gum tin.
lines.text_raw: Gather your empty Altoids gum tin.

lines.text: Cut or Dremel two notches in the end of the tin around the area where the flat part ends and the tin starts to round out.
lines.text_raw: Cut or Dremel two notches in the end of the tin around the area where the flat part ends and the tin starts to round out.

lines.text: Bend this flap back and forth and break it off.
lines.text_raw: Bend this flap back and forth and break it off.

lines.text: Place the pieces of sticky tape on the bottom of the battery holder and on the bottom of the circuit board.
lines.text_raw: Place the pieces of sticky tape on the bottom of the battery holder and on the bottom of the circuit board.

lines.text: It is important that there is no contact between the circuit board and the metal enclosure.  This would cause a short in the circuit.
lines.text_raw: It is important that there is no contact between the circuit board and the metal enclosure.  This would cause a short in the circuit.

lines.text: Insert everything into the tin and then insert the batteries.  Close the tin, and you are finished!
lines.text_raw: Insert everything into the tin and then insert the batteries.  Close the tin, and you are finished!
